titleproper.value:
Guide to the Mark Solomon and Robert Kaufman Research Files on African Americans and Communism
                    <num>TAM.218</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Processed by Katja Vehlow, 2001

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:03-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Mark Solomon and Robert Kaufman Research Files on African Americans and Communism

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The collection is comprised of research materials regarding African Americans and communism accumulated by two scholars: Mark Solomon and Robert Kaufman. It contains clippings, articles, printed ephemera, internal documents, published documents (principally from radical organizations), research notes, and government surveillance documents.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

Mark Solomon is the author of 
                <title render="italic">The Cry Was Unity: Communists and African Americans, 1917-1936</title>(1988). He taught U.S. history at Simmons College from 1967 to 1997. The late Robert Kaufman created/accumulated his portion of this collection during research at the University of California, Berkeley on his (never completed) doctoral thesis on African American labor and communism.

The collection is organized into two series, each containing topical files arranged alphabetically: I. Mark Solomon Research Files; II. Robert Kaufman Research Files. The collection contains clippings, printed ephemera, internal and published documents, principally from radical organizations, research notes, and some government documents (surveillance of radicals).

subject.value: African American labor union members |x History.
Labor unions and communism |z United States.
